posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Whether unarmed or dual kamas are better depends on what level magic items are available on the server. If the best you can get is less than +6, then unarmed is better, but over +6 (and especially with elemental damage) then dual kamas are better. I might be wrong about that cutoff point. It might be +5 or +7 or so. I don't think it's as low as +4 nor as high as +8.

If you take 16 Monk and then 4 Fighter, you will get one more attack per round (6 instead of only 5). Then you take your 6 levels of SD. After that, you can choose to take 2 Fighter and 2 Monk to get Epic Weapon Specialization, or take 4 Monk to get +1 AC and immunity to mental effects. With that combination of classes (9 or more Monk and 5 or more SD) you could in theory get Epic Dodge, which makes it harder to hit you.

posts.author: Tyris2222
posts.content: Is there an advantage to have points in spot and listen?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Spot checks against a static hider.  Listen vs. hider when in motion.  A successful Spot check would prevent accidental wading into a mass of waiting, hidden opponents.  Listen can detect movement around corners, but again, they must be moving before the check is made. The Spot check is always rolled first.  If the skill points are available, it's best to get both as high as possible for detection.

Spot means diddly-squat for a true seers.  Same goes for Listen except for the case described above... movement outside LOS.  That single anomaly is the reason many players will max Listen before Spot.

posts.author: Tyris2222
posts.content: Was looking at the yardstick builds, would you say that you get a better monk if you just stay pure?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
The answer comes down to feats. And that is not a dynamic build concept unique to monks.

"Pure" builds are seldom superior to multiclass because of the significant benefits that those other classes can lend to the toon.  The main exception are the pre-epic (< Lvl 21) environments since many class feats before epic tend to be valuable and competitive with any class feats/benefits another class might offer.  The fewer pre-epic levels possible, the stronger a pure class build becomes.  By inserting secondary/tertiary classes will often dilute the strengths of the primary class.  SoU is a perfect example.  Except for the prospect of developing the character further in HotU up to Lvl 28-ish, pure Monk 12-14 as a stand-alone cap is probably the strongest choice.

To illustrate further, let's assume the level limitations of your Level 30 cap environment with a monk naked or wearing robes, no shield, unarmed or kama focus...

So compare a Monk 30 to a Monk 20/Secondary X/Tertiary Y.  First, focus on the class feats affected by monk level (I hope I have remembered them all... you can check though):

Monk 30 - AC bonus: +6, stun 7x/day, move speed +100%, heal 60HP 1x/day, SR 40 (unbreachable), QPalm DC 25 + WIS mod, 50% conceal 3 turns 2x/day
Monk 20 - AC bonus: +4, stun 5x/day, move speed +60%, heal 40HP 1x/day, SR 30 (unbreachable), QPalm DC 20 + WIS mod, 50% conceal 2 turns 2x/day

Monk 30 - 5 APR
Monk 20 - 6 APR with minimum 4 pre-epic combat class levels

Monk 30 - 2 class bonus feats (ImpSR, ImpKi, ImpStun)
Monk 20 - No class bonus feats

There will also be a difference in universal saves when 20 monk levels not taken during pre-epic. (Monk is only class with a all high base saves.)

The 10 non-monk-example was just chosen at random.  Typically, only a few levels of a complimentary class are taken (eg. SD 1 for HiPS, Ftr 4 for APR & WS, CoT 4 for APR & saves, to cite a few common ones) so monk levels will be more within the 25-29 range.  Also, the multiclass BAB will suffer without combat class levels.  Use rule of 4 whenever you use mid class pre-epic.

I'll leave it to you to decide where the cost/benefits of the class-specific feats begin to become subject to diminishing returns.  It really depends on what you are focusing on but generally-speaking, there is more to be gained by multiclassing than what 30 pure levels of monk provide. A stealthy ED monk/rogue is particularly strong not only for the speedy high-APR sneaks but with UMD a monk can become near invincible. Factors which cannot be anticipated by anyone other than the player itself are roleplay and server nerfs to classes and feats.  Only you can decide what takes the most advantage.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Improved Ki is useful only if you are playing in an environment so low-magic that you will not find any monk gloves better than +3. I always use my first Monk bonus feat for Armor Skin.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
Improved Ki is useful only if you are playing in an environment so low-magic that you will not find any monk gloves better than +3. I always use my first Monk bonus feat for Armor Skin.
I agree.  Even the +5 Ki feat isn't worth it under most circumstances, though that one will penetrate Stoneskin, Premonition & other similar DR effects.  Note that Ki strike does not add AB or damage, like the gloves would.  It's just an anti-DR counter (not to be confused with WM's Ki damage boost feat).

In the comparison I detailed though, I only listed the monk-specific bonus feats since any class can take the general ones like Armor Skin, Epic Prowess or EDR... so the monk ones are the only opportunities you'd miss out on by multiclassing. In the case of comparing, say a Monk 20/Fighter 10 to a Monk 30, there would be 6 fighter bonus feats vs. the measly 2 monk during the same 10 levels.  IMO only the AC and SR boost are worthy considerations, with the monk bonus feats not a reason to stay pure for an entire level 30 build.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
If you get your Tumble skill where it needs to be (40 unmodified ranks) Spring Attack will become a superfluous feat.  While you are moving, you will be tumbling away from all AoOs.  Not to mention another +2 AC is there to be gleaned.

I wouldn't hesitate to ignore heal skill completely. If you want to increase the skill beyond the enhancement of the kit, chug an Owl's potion before using the skill. Don't forget that you get a Take20 for the skill check when not in combat which should cure most ills automatically by itself.  I would move 10 to Tumble and 10 to Discipline (max it).  With all that Dex, even though your stealth skills haven't been maxed, you should be evading detection reliably enough.

Otherwise, it looks like you have it figured out. Congrats!  Time to play-test.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Tyris2222 wrote:
Thank guys, it seems to be coming down to Epic Dodge vs UMD and being able to self-buff.
Not necessarily.

It could come down to ED/UMD vs +1BAB/+1APR/+6 dmg with Rog5/SD6/Monk 19 (or thereabouts) vs your Ftr build version.  You may need to adjust your starting ability spread slightly. 

A Str12/Dex18/Con12/Wis8/Int14/Cha8 human works. I liked the extra AB early on for when finesse kicks in.  Depending on how high a monk level you prefer will determine the amount and frequency of Rog UMD dumps. At rogue 10, you could get crippling strikes which are effective against all creature types.  A 30-cap build will need to max the skill (Rog dump@30)  to use Level 9 scrolls without casting failure with the help of an Eagle pot Cha boost beforehand.  Aim for a modified UMD 33.

The non-fighter version will be more skilled doing less intrinsic damage but a better sneaker depending on how you split monk/rogue levels.  Sneak attacks could compensate for the loss of EWS and with HiPS, there will be plenty of opportunities to take advantage of.  Monk progression combined with SA is quite good.

Personally, I feel UMD under most environments is an overpowering skill.  It allows a meleer to magically enhance both defense and attack with mundane equipment.  A mage would need to polymorph to take advantage of the same kind of enhancements but their APR will always be lower.  Rogue, bard or assassin has a way of showing up in most of my unconstrained builds as long as UMD has not been nerfed.

For me, it comes down to whether you want to rely on party buffs to extend this toon's combat prowess or not.  With ample support, the UMD benefits would be mostly from being able to equip otherwise unusable items and in that case the added attack prowess from the fighter levels would dominate.  Solo adventuring, the high UMD version will more than compensate for the lost specialization and attack rate, though. 

Decisions, decisions. :P

edit:  Two questions I forgot to ask previously: Are 6 levels of SD needed in the environment you are planning to play this to get HiPS?  The way you are describing this seems to indicate you won't get HiPS until SD 6.  Also, is there a minimum number of levels to be taking before invoking the next class change?  I seem to remember one server (Arelith?) requiring 3 levels before multiclassing and 3 before returning.  In other words, they discourage/prevent early dump levels.
